ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Maureen is by far my best professor since I enrolled in Yale. She has a great talent in teaching.
Extremely valuable course for all environmental managers. I wish I had more opportunities to practice this type of financial analysis in other courses.

Maureen is a FANTASTIC teacher, and condensed core financial concepts into clear lectures. Though the pace of the course was rather quick, it was understandable given time constraints, and I have zero complaints on my end. I hope to have her as a teacher next year to teach intermediate/advanced financial concepts.

Lectures were fast paced but notes provided online were very helpful. Felt like lectures were unnecessary and most of the homework was trying to find the answers in the notes and powerpoint lectures. A lot of work for a one credit course. Felt like I didn't understand much material and ended up copying and pasting from in class assignments and examples in the notes and powerpoint lectures.
Maureen is an amazing teacher, runs through a great amount of material with clarity and ease. Is very good at bringing concepts down to earth and giving students individual attention.

Question 4: The material was very useful but the pace of the course was too fast. It should be made into a regular full-semester course and be offered for more than one credit as the coursework load was also quite heavy for one unit.
Great class!
The course is large so it is difficult for the professor to respond to questions in class. The lectures generally follow the slides so I feel the lectures are somewhat redundant.
The class moved at a fast pace and could benefit from a culling of topics explored.

I was unable to get a good handle on the material because it was too substantial for the time period during which it was taught. I recommend that the professor teach only the most important concepts so that students have time to actually absorb/retain the material.
This is a good course but goes way too quickly for people who do not have a background in this field.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The professor's clarity in explaining concepts both in class and in her lecture notes.
In class exercises and very practical basic financial skills.
HW and in-class excercises helped to ensure better understanding of course materials
Available summaries of topics in pdfs.
The cases that went through the entire class were very helpful.
The homework was exciting and fun.
The course covers a broad range of financial concepts in just a 6 week timeframe.
The presentation slides and excel worksheet were very well constructed and could be followed easily.
Coursework was highly relevant and helpful; she provided all the necessary guidance in class for us to understand and get the most out of the assignments.
I really liked the assignment where we used Google Finance.
Covered a variety of topics
Great exercises and class-content. Very complete and helpful for career and future class work.
It is VERY important for FES students to have a grasp of financial concepts.
Range of topics covered.
This course provides a concrete skill set, especially for only a one-hour time commitment. Maureen is kind, funny, and understanding. Online resources and office hours provided useful support.

Though the course material was very basic, it was extraordinarily helpful for someone with no accounting background. I now feel like I have at least a minimal grasp of important considerations and terminology that will help me in my future career field.
I feel the topic of the material- although not my favorite- is practical and will be valuable in my life after FES.
The exercises were helpful, but some of them were so rigorous and the instructions were sometimes wrong and or not helpful.
A lot of material was covered in a short time period. Instructor was receptive to student queries.

The course presents basic financial concepts in a very practical way and makes it easy for anyone to join a financially related conversation, as well as read and analyze the basic financial documents.
The ability to practice the problems in class before engaging with the material for homework was key.
Maureen is a great instructor and very helpful and attentive to the students. This was impressive especially given how large the class is.
Well organized clear explanation of concepts
The homeworks were good practice.
I gained a decent amount of exposure to a variety of topics in this field.

The assignments were essential to learn the concepts taught in class. The exercises in class were also very important, as well as the material the professor provided. The material is very well prepared and clear, and provide all the necessary instructions to the students.
Acessible to folks without a strong quantitative background.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The time. Should be changed from 6 - 8pm to 4 -6pm
While this is somewhat the nature of a 6-week, once-per-week course, it was difficult to keep up with the pure volume of information. The content is pretty dense and requires a lot of practice.
Clarity of pdfs of the lectures...additional material from what's simply presented in the ppts may have been more helpful?
Many of the lectures were slow, repetitive, and confusing.
I wish it could have been a few weeks longer.
Please make sure the instructions are clear for assignments. Sometimes they lacked clarity and sometimes wrong information was given. That get confusing more than anything else.
Slower pace? Otherwise, none.
The good fish example was a little annoying.

This course could be taught as a flipped course and more time spent in class on the in class assignments and working through examples. I felt like I didn't understand most of the concepts introduced in this class. This course should be two units.
Needs to be made into a full-semester course and offered for more credit.

Because the class is rather late (6-8pm) it is hard to concentrate with the current format of 1 hour lecture and then in-class exercise. Is there any way to involve students more in content or break up the 1st hour of lecture?

This class should be a semester long and offered in the Fall. Often FES students do not have adequate finance and accounting background to meaningfully participate in SOM classes. Having a full semester FES course on finance and accounting would help, possibly as core class for certain specializations like business or energy. Also, the class was offered from 6-8pm which is not an ideal time for learning!
Cut back a few topics and focus in on a few others.
A very brief introduction to Excel formulas with the first couple of classes would be very helpful.
It's great that we have access to Professor Burke's powerpoint slides, but the clarity and explanations on the slides could be improved.

It's difficult with such a large course and so much material to go through, but more interaction between the students and professor would be helpful to ensure uptake of the material and enliven the lectures. Perhaps this means offering this course both semesters.
More TA's and more hours for help with the assignments.
Too fast paced and heavy on excel.

There could be more sessions of the class: besides the general lecture and the office hours of the TAs, it will be nice to have actual sessions with the TAs. I am still not 100% confident in my ability to understand indicators such as ROE, ROI etc.
I really think this should be a semester long course. It is far too much material to meaningfully understand in just 6 weeks.
The powerpoints are painfully boring
Amount of material (number of topics taught)- needs to be reduced.

The pace is too fast. It might have been caused by the amount of information and the length of the course (6 weeks), but it could be valuable to check if all the information given is fundamental or if there is any chance to still tailor the concepts to make it more digestible.
It should be a whole semester.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Course lectures and discussion/sessions were fantastic!
N/A

Class-lecture and homework where very well designed and helped to apply the concepts learned in class straight away! Thank you for TA's for the great work. They very always very helpful and responsive!
There was discussion in class,but there is simply not enough time to digest all the information.
Homework was effective in reinforcing lecture content.
N.A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course has given a solid foundation for advanced courses in finance such as Financial Instruments and Contracts.
This class helped me gain confidence with financial modeling, valuation, and interpretation of financial statements. All of these skills are useful for environmental managers.
You need finance, trust me, no matter what you do.
This is a great primer for all things finance-- I think it is an important course that all FES students should take to have some idea of financial concepts.
Financial concepts would be very relevant for anyone if only I actually understood any of the concepts that were introduced.
Provides a really strong review of rusty college financial accounting, as well as new knowledge on financial analysis

Because I did not have any background in finance before this class really helped understand the crucial and basic concepts which are important for my focus in business and the environment! Great class!!
Will be a project manager soon and will need project budgeting skills and ways to evaluate multiple possible projects- all which I learned the basics of in this course.
It's important to understand th financial world--while it wasn't about environmental NGO's I still think it was helpful to take it.

Even for people with economic background, the course is an excellent concise revision of important and fundamental concepts. At the same time there is not too much depth into the material, but rather a basic understanding so that environmentalists from diverse backgrounds can be on the same page with business people for example.
I've taken some finance classes at SOM, so it was kind of unnecessary
It gives environmental managers with limited financial knowledge some exposure to these topics. While I don't feel fully up to speed, I have a basic understanding of some of these concepts.

Learning the fundamentals of finance is useful in environmental project management, corporate engagement, greening markets, understanding the opportunities and challenges of incorporating environmental considerations into business, and more.

I am trying to learn more on how to bring more financial resources to forest conservation and restoration in tropical areas, so It's very important to have an idea about a profitable investment and how to measure that. However, I am not just focused on business, but also in the third sector, which is missing in this course.
It provides an overview of financial concepts especially when there are discussion about finances and economics tied to environmental issues.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took this course to obtain a foundation in finance for future course in financial instruments and contracts.
I chose to take this class because I wanted to have some understanding of financial concepts for future jobs
These are topics everyone should have a common understanding of.
I felt that I needed a stronger basis in accounting and finance.
To gain financial literacy.
I wanted to get a general understanding of financial and account principles.
I needed finance.
I wanted to get a fundamental understanding of financial analysis, which was precisely what I got.
Totally new to me, and a prereq for more classes I want to take in finance.
Thought it would be helpful for non profit management in the future.
The material is useful for any career path chosen.

Good knowledge of basic finance/accounting concepts and knowledge of the broad spectrum of finance! (but also my passion & interest in it - which I actually discovered thanks to this class! thank you Marian!)
To get some basic financial concepts to prepare for additional courses.
To learn basic financial concepts.
To achieve a greater understanding of the accounting concepts that businesses use to make everyday decisions.
To get exposure to basic financial skills.
To understand more about financial concepts.
A basic understanding of financial concepts will be key to my summer internship and, potentially, future career.
To get a foundational understanding of finance to add to my vocabulary for business and the environment field.
I wanted to be conversant in finance lingo.
Needed the extra credit.
To have some exposure to financial topics, especially in the context of natural resource management.

I am trying to learn more on how to bring more financial resources to forest conservation and restoration in tropical areas, so It's very important to have an idea about a profitable investment and how to measure that.
The course provide an understanding of financial concepts for students who will not be engaging in the business sector directly.
To improve my knowledge in this field .

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
For the most part. I didn't have specific expectations, so I do know more than prior to the class and I think the concepts will be valuable in my career.
Yes, but I need to practise more in order not to lose the knowledge.
Not really- but I had already taken similar courses. This was slower than I thought it would be.
YES.

Yes, the course did a good job of providing introduction to several concepts. In a six week course some nuances will be glossed over, obviously. As a result I don't think I would be comfortable applying the concepts in a high stakes situation, but it's useful to have a conceptual grounding in what sort of steps we go through in assessing the financial plans of new or existing businesses.
Yes.
Yes... I wish it was a full length course though.
No, didn't understand majority of the material. Glad I have access to very detailed notes to refer to in the future.
Yes!!
I didn't feel like I actually 'learned' much of the material as the course was moving too fast with a heavy workload.
Yes definitely.
Not exactly- the short timeframe of the class combined with power point teaching style and no exams made it more challenging for the content to really sink in.
Yes
I think the class had too much information to cover, and some of the information was said not to be relevant to us, so why to include it in the class material?
Yes.
Yes
Yes.
In some ways yes, but in other ways no.
Yes, although I would have liked to practice more.
Yes.
yes.
Yes
Yeah
Somewhat. I felt overwhelmed and wasn't able to fully retain a lot of the material.
I am still figuring out how to use what I learn.

I think it would have been nice to have more practice opportunities. Perhaps this course might be offered as a full three credit class in order to give students the opportunity to apply the concepts more extensively.

Yes, but the course is too fast and the school can consider expanding the class to a 2 or 3 credit class over the full semester focusing on green business not just in the private sector but also in the public sector.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A
N/A
Wish the TA's in the course would be more responsive during class time to go around and help students during the in class assignments.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: The course is an excellent introductory course to finance. The professor is excellent in a teaching and students would come out with solid foundation in introductory finance.
Form groups to work through the homework sets - its really helpful to have others around you as you work through the material. TA sessions were also very helpful for clarifying concepts.
Do the homework early, ask questions if you're confused, and collaborate with friends to support learning outside of class.
The level of this course was about right for me, based on my goals. If you have more interest or time to devote to the subject, you might look into courses at SOM.
Take the course. You need finance more than you realize.
Stay on top of your work! The difficulty of the material is very reasonable, and you should have little trouble with it if you keep up with the topics covered in class each week.
Take it.
Definitely take it as a refresher to accounting.

If you have no background in finance or accounting some of the concepts in this course can be difficult to understand and are not presented in such a way that is understandable for someone with no background knowledge in these concepts. The homework takes way more work than would be expected from a one unit course.
its very useful course - must need for professional students

This course offers you basics in finance and accounting. Although it is very fast pace it is really helpful and you learn the basic concepts and skills you need. Definitely worth taking. Marian is a great professor. She is very patient and helpful. However, because the class is rather late (6-8pm) make sure you eat something small before hand or take an energy-drink to stay concentrated. It is also definitely worth investing in your homework because they allow you to apply the content straight away!
Encourage FES to offer it as a full semester course that begins 9am sharp!

I think it is more work for a 6 week course than many other 6 week courses. But worthwhile to take if you want to get a basic understanding of financial concepts. Just plan accordingly, I feel like I could have done better if I didn't have a big workload in addition to this class.

Refer to the lecture notes and slides before completing homework and then take full advantage of office hours to ask homework questions. Finally, take fifteen minutes to become proficient in Excel formulas before completing Excel-based homework to save lots of frustration!
Great course to take if you want a primer on how businesses make investment decisions.
Take it, and keep practicing the skills!
This course is straightforward- do the assignments on time as this is where you'll really find out if you understand the content or not.
Make sure you understand excel first, or assignments will take much longer (or perhaps that's the point--that it helps you learn how to use excel as well).
Pay attention in class and don't be overwhelmed by how excel oriented it is.
Take it! It is a short class which is also an advantage in its own, so it will not put too much additional work, but still familiarize you with basic financial and accounting concepts.
Seek out clarification from the TAs both before and after the homework is due
If you're just looking to gain some basic accounting knowledge and lingo, it's useful.

Be aware that the course is fast-paced and covers a lot of ground, so don't fall behind. If you want to get the most out of the course/retain as much of the material as possible, get help regularly from the TAs. Not only will they help you complete the homework assignments, they will also ensure that you understand what you are doing and why it is relevant.
Be up-to-date with the assignments and do all of them. Make sure to arrive early in class to have the change to hear the explanations for all the assignments.
This is just a very brief overview providing understanding for key financial terms. For a more detailed course, you may like to look for alternative classes in SOM.
Make sure you have time to spend on the homeworks.
